entry.title: üöÄ ADK v/s MCP ü§î: Frenemies or Superfriends? How These Tools Supercharge AI Development! üß†‚ö°
entry.summary:
(Spoiler: Together, They‚Äôre Unstoppable!) Imagine building a Robot army ü§ñ‚öîÔ∏è (ADK) that can also hack into every database on Earth üîì (MCP). That‚Äôs the power combo we‚Äôre unpacking today! Forget "vs." ‚Äî let‚Äôs merge Google‚Äôs Agent Development Kit (ADK) and Model Context Protocol (MCP) to create AI systems that - Think Act Adapt .......like never before. Buckle up! (Build armies of AI agents that work like a hive mind!) üí° What Makes ADK a Game-Changer? Python-Powered Simplicity: Code agents in minutes, not months. Dynamic Teams: Agents delegate tasks like a CEO (e.g., "Hey FinanceBot, handle the invoice while I chat with the customer!"). Multimodal Magic: Voice, video, text‚ÄîNetflix-style interactions for AI üé•üîä. üõ†Ô∏è ADK‚Äôs Weakness: It‚Äôs data-hungry but lacks direct access to your private files, calendars, or APIs. That‚Äôs where MCP swoops in!
(Your LLM‚Äôs backstage pass to the real world!) üí° Why MCP is the Silent Hero Universal Plug-and-Play: Like USB-C for AI‚Äîconnect Claude to Google Drive, GitHub, or even your smart fridge üßÉ. Privacy-First: Data access only after user consent (no creepy overreach!). Real-Time Context: Agents see your world, not just the open web. ‚ö° Killer Feature: Prompts as Superpowers Define triggers like /check-calendar to let AI act before you ask. üõ†Ô∏è MCP‚Äôs Weakness: It‚Äôs a connector, not a builder. You need ADK (or similar) to create agents that use those connections.
Example: Build a Personal Assistant That‚Äôs Smarter Than J.A.R.V.I.S
Step 1: Use MCP to link: Your Google Calendar üìÖ Work emails üìß Fitness tracker üèãÔ∏è‚ôÇÔ∏è Result: Your assistant auto-reschedules meetings if your Fitbit detects stress‚Äîwithout coding APIs from scratch ü§Ø.
ADK = Conductor üéª MCP = Orchestra‚Äôs instruments üé∫ You = The Composer üéº ADK and MCP aren‚Äôt rivals‚Äîthey‚Äôre peanut butter and jelly ü•úüçá. Ready to experiment? ADK Docs: github.com/google/adk MCP Specs: modelcontextprotocol.io

entry.title: Trying to Type Faster? Meet TypeWin
entry.summary:
Howdy folks üëãüèª
If you use a computer ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs for programming, writing, or just everyday tasks ‚Äî chances are you rely on your keyboard more than you think. From crafting blog posts and coding projects to drafting books or simply replying to emails, typing is a core part of your digital life. Most people type at an average speed of 10 to 50 words per minute (WPM), which gets the job done, but it leaves a lot of room for improvement. The good news? With just a little focused daily training, you can dramatically boost your typing speed and accuracy, unlocking a faster, smoother workflow. Like any speed measurement unit, KPH or MPH for example, it's basically how many words you can type in a minute. According to a survey done in March 2025 by onlinetyping.org on 56,000 volunteers, 28‚Ä¶

entry.title: Heads-Up Android Devs: 16KB Page Size Support Required by Nov 2025
entry.summary:
tarting November 1, 2025, Google Play will require all new apps and app updates targeting Android 15+ to be compatible with 16KB memory pages. Here's what that means for you and how to get your app ready. üì¶ Why This Matters üìà Real-world benefits seen on devices with 16KB pages: App launch time: up to 30% faster Battery life: ~4.5% improvement Camera startup: 4.5‚Äì6.6% faster System boot: ~8% faster ‚úÖ Is Your App Affected? You don‚Äôt use native code or native libraries You need to check compatibility if: You‚Äôre building native extensions or relying on native SDKs üõ†Ô∏è How to Make Your App 16KB-Compatible Audit Your Dependencies Test in 16KB Environments Use APK Analyzer üîç How to Test Use the APK Analyzer to flag potential issues Check the .so files and linked symbols for assumptions about 4KB pages ‚è≥ What If You Don't Update? üß™ Bonus: Use This Gradle Snippet to Warn Early groovy android { lintOptions { checkReleaseBuilds true warningsAsErrors true } }
Combine that with static analysis or custom lint rules to catch compatibility issues early in CI. üîó Resources NDK Downloads Android Studio 16KB Emulator Support üí¨ Have you started testing your app with 16KB pages? Any issues with native libraries or build tools? Let‚Äôs discuss in the comments üëá

In this tutorial, we walk through how to build a simple yet powerful app for user authentication and registration using the Python framework Flask. Here‚Äôs what we covered: ‚úÖ Setting up the project structure and connecting a SQLite database to store user data Check out the full tutorial here https://hostman.com/tutorials/creating-a-web-application-using-python-flask/

entry.title: üöÄ Introducing MCPX: A Gateway for Governing AI Agent Tool Usage
entry.summary: As more teams start experimenting with AI agents using MCP, one challenge keeps coming up - there's no clear way to govern how agents access tools, or understand what's happening when those tools are called. That‚Äôs why we built MCPX - an open-source gateway that helps you add visibility, guardrails, and permissioning around MCP usage. Whether you're testing locally or building toward more complex workflows, MCPX gives you control over how agents interact with your tool ecosystem. Check it out: MCPX on GitHub We‚Äôre seeing real traction in teams using MCP to let agents call tools like Slack, GitHub, Gmail, internal APIs, and more. But the operational gaps are clear: Agents can call tools they shouldn‚Äôt No way to group or gate sensitive actions No built-in audit or usage tracking No policies ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Choosing Your Developer Path Series: Don‚Äôt Wait for Permission to Grow
entry.summary: In the next few weeks, I‚Äôll explore with you how to choose a developer path: from technical deep dives to people leadership, and everything in between. Whether you‚Äôre at a fork in the road or just getting curious, this series is for you. Week 1 will be about exploring (experimentation, choosing a growth theme), Week 2 we'll focus on becoming visible and taking initiative, while the final week is about claiming growth (or moving away) and choosing your own path. Join me on this journey! ‚ÄúI want to grow, but I don‚Äôt know what my next step is.‚Äù Sound familiar? So many developers stay stuck in neutral, waiting: For their manager to notice For a formal opportunity For the ‚Äúright‚Äù timing For confidence to magically appear But: You don‚Äôt need permission to grow. You need initiative. I wasn‚Äôt hand‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 Common React Mistakes New Developers Make (and How to Fix Them)
entry.summary:
Hey React developers, After working with dozens of developers and reviewing lots of React code, I‚Äôve noticed a pattern. Many developers write code that works fine during development but leads to subtle bugs and frustrating user experiences in production. These issues often show up when real users interact with the app, leading to bounce rates, lost user trust, or even lost revenue. In this post, I‚Äôll break down 10 common mistakes I see (and have made myself), plus practical ways to fix them. The goal: move from "it works on my machine" to "this feels great for everyone." const [search, setSearch] = useState('');
State is stored in memory only. Refreshing the page resets filters. You can‚Äôt share a filtered view. The URL doesn‚Äôt reflect the UI state. Use useSearchParams for simple cases: co‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Domino Effect: How One Tiny Bug Can Kill Your Startup
entry.summary:
The $440 Million Typo That Changed Everything
In 2012, Knight Capital made a "small" software update. One tiny bug in their trading system caused a chain reaction that lost $440 million in 45 minutes. The company almost went bankrupt. One bug. 45 minutes. Nearly dead. This is the domino effect in action. Think of your app like a house of cards. Touch one card wrong, and the whole thing collapses. In software: Fix one bug ‚Üí Create two new bugs Change one line of code ‚Üí Break three features Update one library ‚Üí Crash the entire app It's not just theory. It's happening right now to startups everywhere. Website crashes = Lost customers Payment bugs = Lost revenue Data corruption = Lost trust But here's what really destroys startups - the cascade: Day 1: Small checkout bug appears Day 2: Cus‚Ä¶

KS Wallet Explained: A Developer-Friendly Web3 Wallet Built for Scale
entry.summary: The rise of decentralized applications (dApps) has brought wallets to the forefront of the Web3 experience. As the interface between users and the blockchain, wallets must strike the right balance between usability, security, and flexibility. KS Wallet, developed as part of the KALP STUDIO ecosystem, redefines what a Web3 wallet can be. More than just a place to store digital assets, it serves as a multi-functional gateway to decentralized networks, tailored for both everyday users and developers building on Kalp. This article explores the core functionalities, architecture, and unique advantages of KS Wallet ‚Äî and why it matters for the next generation of blockchain applications. KS Wallet is a multi-format, secure, and scalable Web3 wallet built into the KALP STUDIO platform. It supports‚Ä¶

entry.title: Showcase Your GitHub Repository‚Äôs Users in the README [< 5 Mins]
entry.summary:
If you‚Äôve ever published a library on GitHub, you‚Äôve probably noticed that GitHub shows a nice sidebar section on some repositories ‚Äî "Used by X repositories" ‚Äî giving your project social proof and discoverability.
Unfortunately, this info is only visible if 100+ repositories depend on your project. That sucks because I maintain several open source libraries like jekyll-auto-authors that have dozens of real users and I'd love to showcase that information despite the thresholds. So I built dependents.info ‚Äî a simple tool that shows your network dependents right inside your README!
How it works
The idea is simple: dependents.info is a GitHub Action written in TypeScript + a Go based API that together generate a SVG image showing which repositories depend on your package. Just‚Ä¶

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide to Run Llama 4 Locally with Tool Calling Enabled
entry.summary: The open-source model ecosystem is moving fast, and Llama 4 is one of the most powerful and flexible model families available today. Built with native multimodality, Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture, and support for tool calling, Llama 4 opens up a world of possibilities across text, code, and vision. With the recent release of Ollama v0.8, developers can now leverage real-time streaming responses and tool invocation directly from their GPU Virtual Machines. Whether you‚Äôre building assistants, agents, or research tools, the combination of Llama 4 and Ollama makes it possible to run highly capable models locally with precision and control. Native Multimodal: Accepts both text and image input Supports 12+ Languages: Arabic, English, French, German, Hindi, Indonesian, Italian, Portuguese‚Ä¶
